A FOURTH, REVISED AND FRESHLY UPDATED, EDITION OF THE ZEBRAS BOOK IS SORELY NEEDED Such a 4th edition, coming nearly 20 years after the third one, would be much more valuable to the whole of mankind (well, at least that segment in the stress-loaded Western world) than any new formidable, encyclopedic coverage of some new aspect of neurobiology. We can only hope that Prof. Sapolsy still has enough drive and energy to revive his old flame.  Our Incredibly Learned Professor is now 65 and retired. Not a chance that we'll ever get a new fresh series of lectures. The available ones are those already filmed and recorded. However, I still have a special request to our Incredibly Learned Professor.  His most effective impact on the masses of common people now living on our planet is not just through the diffusion of this magnificent series of lectures of scientific research. It is even more so through his famous  ZEBRAS book, the one that made his reputation as a world expert on stress. And it is indeed an immensely valuable book for us, common Joes, since it. offers a clear and simple treatment of the roughly 20 major basic problems of daily existence and survival confronting PRACTICALLY EVERYBODY IN OUR MODERN WORLD. For instance, beyond ulcers and fleeing hungry lions on the savannah, digestion, eating, obesity, diabetes, heart disease, strokes, anxiety, sex, pain, depression, memory, sleep, type A personalities, aging, addiction, etc..This book can in effect serve as a guide on how to understand the mechanisms of those complex challenges of survival in our technological world, and also how to cope with them. So my request to our Incredibly Learned Professor is simple. Not a few more scientific lectures or cultural videos, but a new edition of his famous book,  WHY ZEBRAS DON'T GET ULCERS. That would be the 4th edition, reprising the 3d edition of 2004. This would give our Incredibly Learned Professor the occasion to review and revise his text of nearly 20 years ago and, as an  unexpected bonus, expand it, if he should find in his waning years the time, the heart, and the energy for this 4th edition. The difficulty is that by now Professor Sapolsky has become more interested in the grander, larger picture of total human behavior, as in his recent book of BEHAVE (2017). He has announced somewhere that he is already involved in preparing another book, which may be another colossal treatment of the existing literature. Whether he will feel inclined at the age of 65 to revisit and improve on his famous book of younger maturity is sadly very doubtful. And if this were so, it would be a huge loss for the millions afflicted by the daily problems analyzed in the ZEBRAS book. For this book considers the common worries and hazards of ordinary people the world over, worries which all are more urgent, more present, more harrowing, than the grand scientific panoramic views in the style of BEHAVE. What are the odds of this 4th edition of the ZEBRAS book — revised, updated and (hopefully) enlarged — seeing the light of day? Very slim, indeed. But, miraculously, our Incredibly Learned Professor may view this new effort as inscribed in the catalogue of his own "better values", reflecting his profound aspirations to improve the lot of all of us,  troubled travelers on our modern, difficult journey.  And, as a special plea,  if this 4th edition ever came out, please, please make sure to also publish a hardback version for the aficionados, while preserving the readability of notes for ordinary eyes.

It's an uplifting finale, though I have some issues with Prof. Sapolsky's scientism and its subsequent cultural misunderstandings. In the same breath he claims that Tibetan Buddhists —of a certain school he says, as if that makes it more palatable— believe in ‘God,’ and that the doctrine of His countless names (certainly not Tibetan Buddhist) is an ‘obvious metaphor.’ The former is just a mistake, however telling; it is the latter which is really problematic. ‘Religious’ doctrines are not primarily intended as metaphors, and even if they are, these are never prima facie ‘obvious’—unless you are already intent on arbitrarily reducing them to something you can relate to (in this case it seems to strengthen the point about the ever-developing nature of knowledge).  The same applies to his many suggestions that demonic possession is an outdated diagnosis of this or that illness. This reductionism does not help to make sense of human cultural diversity, and it is a pity that the representatives of ‘science’ adopt it so uncritically. We need to come up with new, integrative paradigms—and integration doesn’t mean assimilation.

There is a difference in science between the use of the formulae to PREDICT things and the use of those formulae to EXPLAIN things that have already happened.  The latter are called "Emergent Phenomena" and are the result of in the universe its "all the rules, all the time" -- the universe is like the old TV show CANDID CAMERA, where "when its least expected, your elected" to observe something that is seemingly bizarre and contrary to everything you think that you know, but is in reality perfectly consistent with the non-controversial things that have just occurred prior to that rare (sometimes) unexpected event.  This keeps people from being worried about such things since they can be explained as "normal" for that situation, without explaining stuff that nobody is worried about at the moment, since it hasn't been seen (yet).  Did you know that pulling plastic sticky tape off of a roll causes the line where the glue is parting to get so hot that it EMITS X-RAYS?  Now THAT is an unexpected thing, but explainable when you see how much the glue stretches before it tears by looking at it in a microscope.

At what point does OCD come from being thorough in one's work.  I have a mild OCD-like psychology in that when I start a project I can work on it for DECADES and when writing have a problem not putting in too much information to rapidly (words "falling over each other"), so I have to do a lot of editing during and after writing something.  It is a good thing if not too strong, as I know, since things that would make most people bored and quit something do not do this to me very easily (though, of course eventually even I can get fed up with something).  You need this to a small extent to be successful in long-term work, most particularly as a computer programmer where errors take A LOT of debugging and can drive one crazy trying to find something wrong that later one sees as obvious -- VERY frustrating!!  Shows how things can have various effects, even the same problem in different people...

I have noted that the emphasis here (and, it must be stated, very much elsewhere) on "abnormal" behavior is when something goes wrong, from mild autism through the Maasai woman with the goat in her mouth (WOW!).  What about the opposite?  It would seem to me that finding out trends in people like Einstein and other super-achievers of various kinds that are caused by brain "abnormalities" would be an important thing, tool as it would give information on how the brain can be organized in a better way than just normal.  Changes go both ways in our brains, though it is of course easier to degrade things than improve them by changing things.  But evolution is about both things...

Wish my late partner was still around. He had a lifelong struggle with depression and anxiety, and I think he would have found a lot of these lectures fascinating, as well as rigorous, and all without being too academic and obscure. The lecture on schizophrenia was particularly eye opening for me. Boy, am I thankful no one in my family is a sufferer.   The lockdown made me tune into lectures about astronomy and particle physics, but, while I find physics interesting, absent a decent grasp of the underpinning mathematics, it is not a subject that will ever be particularly accessible. I expected the usual of these lectures: that they would be interesting, but would leave me for dust.   Enter Prof. Sapolsky, a born communicator and a gentleman blessed with a crafty wit. Many a time, I laughed aloud, while material I found quite demanding was being conveyed in a painless fashion.

One of the possibly most important subjects that needs further research is plurality.  Any person with an open mind should be capable of seeing that the re-branding of Multiple Personality Disorder to Dissociative Identity Disorder is just constantly trying to avoid the term 'consciousness'. Even though it is understandable that within the pathological version most of these personalities or identities seem more like fragments of a consciousness, or simply 70% or just 10% of a 'full consciousness', there's a lot of moral and ethics that nobody wants to address in this issue. If a fragment has no memory of any other fragments existing, is it okay to still label it as merely a fragment and work against its existence? Does it have free will?  It gets even more complicated within the realm of positive plurality. When you identify yourself as several, at which point are there so many that each one's life quality suffers from it so much that nobody gets a good deal out of it? 10? 100? And if it's 100 different souls, is it okay to supress, merge, inactivate or kill them to increase the life quality for a smaller portion of these forms of consciousness?  In our opinion science is here still heavily under the influence of the demonic possession hypothesis, just not about demons, but about the "one body, one soul" rule established mostly by the big monotheistic religions. If a gene sequence exists that forms the singular consciousness within the mind, it can just as easily be duplicated or read in a way that it simply won't stop producing consciousness. And if it does, where's the boundary of morals? If one of the souls decides to go on a rampage and eradicate everyone else, is that a crime?

During my childhood in the 50s I went to school with a boy who was both poor and epileptic... further it was rumored his father was a ferocious beater. I am certain his epilepsy was untreated. THe only direct bullying of a child I ever saw growing up was when walking as a group to our respective homes after school other boys would sometimes  taunt him verbally.I asked WHY after he dropped out of the group to go inside his house and was told those things about him. I was about 8yrs old..it was the first memory I have of feeling highly empathic for another child and speaking up to try to stop the bullying. I really told off the boy who had taunted him and he slunk away from the rest of us. No one never bullied him again in my earshot.I was shocked that I had done that...the most grievous taunter was a boy older than I. OVer that summer I was  away for the summer. WHen school started I noticed his brother was with the group but no sign of the epileptic boy...I still remember his name Wayne Smalley. I was told he had been swimming  in the river that summer, had a seizure and and had drowned. It was the first time I had a complete picture of a truly horrific and tragic life. I think of him still from time to time with sorrow. The social stigma of epilepsy WAS still around in the 1950s....I think bec it frightened people , the unco trollablitiy of the body and it is scary to behold. Scarier still to have I am sure.   I recently owned a dog who fell off a terrace a few times which gave him closed head trauma, brain bleeds and swelling I am sure because he developed epilepsy. Our vet treated it with phenobarbital...he took ever higher doses for several years til his natural death. I could not bear to have him put down...when he would have a break through seizures we would have to up his dose....and he would seem to have fear in his eyes...it broke my heart......but I think he has been my most loved dog of many I have owned bec he was the most affectionate dog I ever owned. I will,always miss him.with every seizure I would think of that boy I once knew.......

Watched it from start to finish over the course of the past 2 weeks. I'm not a biology student, never was. Flunked out of uni (quite happily) about a decade ago...just an unemployed (or self-employed with a generous interpretation) writer. Any number of lines in the first few lectures must've drawn in fellow English literature students, like 'How many of you believe in free will?' and while an interesting discussion, it's not what really hooked me to finish this course to its end. It's not what assured me that, by the end of this course, I will have felt this lecture was worth it. It was when he began to attack the first bucket and the specific phrase of not wanting to believe in the 'just so' stories that hooked me.   See, the vast majority of writers on this planet are content with nothing but their 'just so' stories. It's what makes their job so much easier than if they had to write something resembling the truth, especially if they're writing fiction (although, to be fair, this tendency for 'just so' stories has never stopped non-fiction journalists from inventing their own distorted mental image of their subjects and misrepresenting them either). To hear a genuine admission, that scientists have many, many times in the past fallen into this exact same trap, simply because they wanted to amplify the importance of their chosen specialized field at the expense of others, was what gave me hope that by the end of this lecture I wouldn't get yet another 'just so' story, a version of which I've almost certainly already read or thought of myself.   Finishing this lecture (as well as the additional two older versions of Depression + Religiosity), I think that what I saw and heard was extremely rare: A storyteller (or lecturer, if you prefer) who gives you something far better than 'just so' stories and their answers; The mental tools to ask better questions about the human condition. Thank you so much for this Robert Sapolsky and those who filmed and put this up on Youtube. Through this 2-week journey of Human Behavioral Biology, you've refreshed my curiosity and my own will (free or not) to write stories designed to share your gift, which is the only thing I've ever seen get me or anyone else, for that matter, even remotely close to the truth and away from the sin of lying to my audience.   And that gift is to ask questions that you would never have considered before and never settle for an easy 'just so' answer.

after reading the book, "The Woman Who Changed her brain", by Barbara Arrowsmith, it really brings Robert's point on the casual separation we imply to the term cognitive "disease" as a true misunderstanding of ourselves as people, and our indifference to others. Bad behaviors are keenly tied to cognitive function in a very normal way, and their effect on negatvie self perception development is more associated to practice, abstract practice of brain development and how strengths and weakness in cognitive variation make up base line behavior. Mix that with human competitive nature, people who are different are forced to learn a incorrect self perception, to give advantage to the more socially adaptive cognitive functions. And that a simple practice of say playing a simple game like reading a traditional clock, can and does, thanks to understanding of neuroplaticity in Barbara's book, does change cognitive differences. It's really a simple matter of the right exercise applied to the right understanding of the deficit. It's so simple that it's a major game changer and can make previous understandings of medicine/teaching seem archaic when people know how the mind really works in response to stimuli.

Thank you, Dr. Sapolsky, this is what I've been saying for so long: it's too easy to just separate the brain abnormalities we can categorize (schizophrenia, OCD, antisocial personality disorder, bipolar disorder, etc.) from us "normal people," when in reality there's no more or less reason to consider the biological underpinnings of the behavior of someone who's "just a jerk" than to do the same for someone with something we can diagnose.  The priority should be on achieving the best balance between protecting people from the harmful behaviors of others, and humanely treating those who exhibit those behaviors.  For some people, this may involve removing a brain tumor, and for others it may require incarceration and rehabilitation, but there's no clear line between the two.  I think instead of focusing on "free will" we would be better off asking, "Is this person likely to repeat this harmful behavior if not treated?  If not punished?  To what degree?" @DavidVonR  I kind of had the opposite experience from you. I was a Christian and avoided looking at the evidence carefully for a long time. And when I finally did look at it with a critical eye, despite being biased heavily in favor of Christianity, I eventually came away not believing in it. I really wanted it to be true and I was very sad that I didn't find justification.  I think the resurrection in particular is a really bad place to start though. Any miracle really, I find it really hard to get around Hume's argument about miracles. Or more particularly, how do you weigh evidence for a natural law being violated. What do you weigh it against? If you look at it in a Bayesian sense, what is your starting probably for a natural law being violated?  If someone looks at my lottery ticket and says it looks like I won the powerball, if I estimate their chance of being wrong as 1 in 1000 and my chance of winning as being 1 in 292,000,000. The chance is overwhelmingly likely that they are just wrong. If I double check and my chances are also 1 in 1000, the chance is still overwhelmingly likely that I'm wrong. If I continue to check and recheck and take the ticket to the office and they check with a computer. Once I rule out dreaming or psychosis etc. eventually I can reasonably conclude that I did indeed win as I will have overcome that starting probability.   But what is the starting probability for a violation of natural law, if you are unbiased? How could you ever have enough evidence to overcome an undefined likelihood? And if you are open to violations of natural law, why only accept one supernatural explanation? Why not let every undefined explanation in? The trickster god is fooling you? You're in a simulation? We all live our own separate realities? Aliens did it? etc. It seems you would need to accept all of these as possibilities if all natural explanations were ruled out and any unknown natural explanations. Of course it's a different story if you are already convinced God exists and regularly performs miracles, then there is some starting probability for you that could be overcome.  If you looked at a magician performing a really solid trick, how long would you scratch your head saying you don't know what the natural explanation is, until you shrug your shoulders and accept that he really just sawed that guy's head off, carried it around the stage and then reattached to the guy's body? I suspect you would likely just say you don't know what happened.   That's the boat I would be in if ever a miracle had some really really solid evidence. But that being said, I have never seen anything very compelling for any miracles. So I'm curious what you have.

+Joe Ruf Agreed.  I think the evolutionary benefit explanation is a sloppy just-so story.   The disease is incredibly rare (5-10 per 100,000 worldwide), and the typical age of onset (> 35) means that for most of human history Huntington's would've had little influence, good or bad, on a carrier's reproductive success.  The simplest explanation is that it's just a very rare genetic error that never faced sufficient selective pressure to be removed from the population.
